questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a prolonged episode of coughing that started 30 minutes ago. His mother says her son was playing with some new toys, including a squirt gun, a robot, and some plastic building blocks he got for his birthday when the symptoms began. The coughing lasted several minutes, after which he was crying but could be soothed by his mother. He is otherwise healthy and his immunizations are up-to-date. He is alert and babbles. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 139/min, respirations are 34/min, and blood pressure is 96/47 mm Hg. The oropharynx is clear and cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender to palpation. X-rays of the chest are shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management?

choices.text: Removal of the foreign body with magnet and nasogastric tube

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Administration of ipecac as an emetic is not recommended as treatment for toxic ingestion. There is insufficient evidence to support that syrup of ipecac improves outcomes in cases of poisoning. Moreover, its side effects, such as lethargy, complicate diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Removal of the battery with a magnet and nasogastric tube would not allow visualization of the esophageal mucosa and any injury that may be present.

C) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and observation would be inappropriate in this case. The alkali material in this battery, which is lodged in the esophagus, can cause chemical burns and injury of the mucosa 2 hours after ingestion, even in an asymptomatic patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Conservative management can be considered if the battery is located in the bowel and the patient is asymptomatic. In this patient with a button battery in an esophageal location, treatment should not be delayed because of the risk of caustic injury from the battery.

E) INCORRECT:

Chelation therapy can be used to manage metal poisoning. While ingestion of a battery containing mercury can elevate blood mercury levels, this patient does not have any symptoms of mercury toxicity, such as intention tremor, ataxia, or psychiatric disturbances.

F) CORRECT:

Emergency endoscopic removal is necessary for all ingested batteries that become lodged in the esophagus. Because alkali material leaking from the battery may cause severe chemical burns 2 hours after ingestion, removal is necessary regardless of whether the patient is symptomatic or not. Removal should not be delayed, even if the patient has eaten. Endoscopic removal allows visualization and assessment of any tissue damage. The position of the negative pole of the battery should also be assessed during endoscopy. The negative pole causes the most severe necrotic injury. Possible complications of a mucosal injury include tracheal stenosis, tracheomalacia, fistula, perforation, and mediastinitis.
questions.hint: The foreign body this patient has ingested is thin, circular, and shows a double-rim (halo) on chest x-ray which indicates that it is a button battery.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of an episode of acute-onset cough, drooling, and dysphagia. One hour earlier, they found him on the floor playing with small magnets from his father's desk and several are now missing. The patient appears well now. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 100/58 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft and nontender abdomen; bowel sounds are normal. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the abdomen shows two round, high-density areas at the level of the stomach. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and observation can be considered if the ingested object is small and blunt (e.g., a coin or a single magnet) and if the patient is asymptomatic and the object is seen passing through the intestines in serial abdominal x-rays. Since this patient ingested multiple magnets that are lodged in the stomach, another step in management is more appropriate at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Most foreign bodies, if small enough, can be managed conservatively with watchful waiting and serial x-ray images performed every 4–6 hours to confirm the passage of the object through the intestines. However, this approach is preferred if a single magnet is ingested or if the magnet has progressed further away from the stomach. This patient ingested multiple magnets that are lodged in the stomach; therefore, another step in management is more appropriate at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Activated charcoal can be used to treat different types of poisoning, including acetaminophen, aspirin, and tricyclic antidepressant poisoning. In order to achieve optimal effectiveness, activated charcoal should be administered within 1–2 hours of ingestion so that it can bind to the poisonous substance and prevent its intestinal resorption. Intestinal absorption of magnets, however, does not occur. Magnet ingestion can cause pressure necrosis of the bowel, perforation, or fistula formation; therefore, another step in management is more appropriate at this time.

D) CORRECT:

Flexible endoscopy is the most appropriate initial step in management for multiple magnets lodged in the esophagus or stomach (after confirmation with an abdominal x-ray). Immediate removal of the ingested magnets is important because they can lead to serious complications (e.g., perforation, volvulus, infection, ileus), especially if the magnet is ingested with a metallic foreign body or if multiple magnets are ingested at different times. Therefore, flexible endoscopy is preferred because it allows any damage to the gastrointestinal wall to be visualized and assessed. If the magnets are further away from the stomach and the patient is asymptomatic, or if a single magnet is ingested, conservative management with serial abdominal x-rays to confirm passage through the intestines can be considered. Alternatively, enteroscopy or colonoscopy can be performed if the magnets can be reached. Surgery may be necessary if the magnets do not progress through the intestines and the patient is symptomatic.

E) INCORRECT:

Laxative therapy (e.g., with polyethylene glycol) usually does not play a role in magnet ingestion. Laxatives are contraindicated in potential gastrointestinal obstruction or perforation because they can worsen the condition.
questions.hint: Ingestion of multiple magnets carries a high risk of gastrointestinal complications.

questions.text: A 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his adult brother because of the ingestion of a coin 1 hour ago. The brother says that he saw the boy playing with their mother's wallet and opening the coin pocket. The brother told the boy to stop, but instead, the boy put a dime into his mouth and swallowed. Following ingestion, the boy had an episode of coughing and initially told his brother that his throat and chest were hurting. He did not vomit and now reports no pain. Medical history is remarkable for a cleft lip at birth, which was managed with cheiloplasty during infancy. Vaccinations are up-to-date. He is at the 50th percentile for height and weight. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 105/60 mm Hg. Examination of the mouth and throat shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender to palpation in the upper quadrants. Lungs are clear to auscultation. An x-ray of the abdomen is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discharge with instructions to observe for spontaneous passage
Admit for serial imaging every 4 hours

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Surgical retrieval of the foreign body is indicated if it causes signs of intestinal obstruction or perforation, if multiple magnets or sharp objects are lodged in the intestine, and in symptomatic patients with magnets located in the intestines. Surgery is not indicated if a coin is lodged in the stomach.

B) CORRECT:

Observation is indicated in patients without severe symptoms with a small, blunt foreign body (e.g., a coin with a diameter < 2.5 cm) located in the stomach, as spontaneous passage through the GI tract is very likely to occur. Outpatient management is appropriate for coins in the stomach or small bowel. A serial x-ray should be performed every 3–4 days, and all stools should be examined to confirm the passage. Complications of coin ingestion are rare, as coins have smooth edges and are composed of nontoxic metals. If complications such as fever, abdominal pain, vomiting, hematemesis, and/or melena develop, urgent endoscopic removal of the foreign body (within 24 hours) is indicated. If the blunt object fails to pass through the gastrointestinal tract within a week, surgical removal can be considered.

Blunt objects with a diameter > 2.5 cm in the stomach are an indication for elective endoscopy, as they are unlikely to pass through the pylorus or ileocecal valve.

C) INCORRECT:

Sucralfate is used as an initial measure in patients with button battery ingestion to reduce esophageal mucosal injury. Sucralfate is not typically used in the management of coin ingestion.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA and lateral views) of a young child

A well-defined disc-shaped metallic foreign body is seen behind the trachea in the upper esophagus. On close inspection, a double rim (dashed lines), or halo (green overlay), is visible on the PA view, which indicates that it is a button battery. A step-off (arrows) to the small diameter anode (hatched green overlay) is seen on the lateral view.

Recognition of a button battery in the esophagus is a pediatric emergency. Radiographs can frequently differentiate button batteries from similarly sized coins and ascertain the direction of the anode, where the most severe damage from the battery occurs. The anode step-off (arrows) may not be visible on some very thin batteries.

D) INCORRECT:

Conservative management with inpatient serial imaging, e.g., every 4–6 hours is indicated in asymptomatic patients with multiple magnets located in the bowel. Complications of magnet ingestion include intestinal pressure necrosis, perforation, and obstruction, which is why inpatient monitoring is required. However, this patient has ingested a coin, which requires a different management approach.

E) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic retrieval is indicated for any type of ingested foreign body causing severe symptoms (e.g., respiratory distress, drooling, or swallowing difficulty) and in patients with button batteries lodged in the esophagus regardless of the presence of symptoms because of the risk of severe burns. Although this patient initially had a coughing episode, he is currently showing no signs of respiratory distress. If the patient develops complications such as fever, abdominal pain, vomiting, hematemesis, or melena, endoscopic retrieval within 24 hours would be appropriate.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (left: AP view; right: lateral view) of a 10-month-old child

A well-defined disc-shaped metallic foreign body (arrows) projects partially over the trachea on the AP view and posterior to the trachea on the lateral view. Close inspection of the foreign body indicates that it is of uniform density. There is no double rim on the AP view or step-off to a small anode on the lateral view to suggest a button battery.

The finding proved to be an ingested coin (illustration) lodged in the esophagus.
questions.hint: The x-ray shows a well-defined disc-shaped radiopaque foreign body of uniform density in the stomach. This finding, in combination with the patient's history, confirms the diagnosis of an ingested coin lodged in the stomach.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents after they noticed her playing with a remote-entry car-key fob. The back of the key fob is missing, and the girl’s parents are unsure if she ingested any of its pieces.
The toddler is happy, playful, and in no acute distress. Vital signs are within normal limits.
An abdominal radiograph reveals a circular object with a halo effect at the lower esophageal sphincter.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this child?

choices.text: Discharge the patient home with plans for a follow-up radiograph in one week

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Activated charcoal is not recommended for foreign-body ingestions, but rather for toxic amounts of poison. Administration should occur within one hour of substance ingestion but is contraindicated for the ingestion of alcohol, glycols, corrosives, such as alkali or acids, and certain metals.

B) INCORRECT:

Discharging this patient home without intervention places her at significant risk for complications, including esophageal or gastric perforation, mediastinitis, or the development of tracheoesophageal fistulae. However, in cases of other small foreign-body ingestions (including coins), discharge with follow-up radiograph is often recommended.

C) INCORRECT:

Ipecac has been shown to be ineffective for foreign-body ingestions.

D) CORRECT:

Button battery ingestions, and the resultant major and fatal outcomes, are becoming more common. Although the vast majority of these ingestions are benign, batteries that lodge in the esophagus can cause serious injury, including serious burns in as few as 2 hours; urgent endoscopic removal should be arranged within this time frame to prevent complications, such as perforation, strictures, fistulas, vocal cord paralysis, or even exsanguination. Delaying intervention until the patient is symptomatic is not appropriate.

Most button battery ingestions occur in children younger than 6 years. Fatality and severe outcomes are most common in children age 11 months to 3 years. Diagnoses are often missed because of nonspecific presenting symptoms, such as fever, drooling, lethargy, poor appetite, irritability, cough, wheezing, and dehydration. Clinicians should have a heightened index of suspicion when evaluating young patients with these symptoms.

Key learning point: The definitive treatment for a child who has ingested a button battery, detected by radiograph in the lower esophagus, is urgent endoscopic retrieval.

E) INCORRECT:

Promotility agents (such as metoclopramide) and laxatives have been shown to be ineffective for foreign-body ingestions.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother immediately after she witnessed him swallowing a nickel, approximately 15 minutes after he had finished eating his evening meal. He has had no symptoms since the episode, including no emesis, noisy breathing, drooling, voice changes, choking, or abdominal pain. He has no history of medical problems.
His vital signs are normal for his age, and his physical examination is within normal limits.
Chest and abdominal radiographs reveal a 2-cm radiopaque, round density in the distal esophagus.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this child?

choices.text: Observe, and repeat the radiograph in several hours
Arrange for rigid endoscopy and removal of the coin under anesthesia
Discharge home, and schedule repeat radiographs in 2 days
Administer syrup of ipecac to induce vomiting

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The best management in this case is to admit the patient for observation with serial radiographs and keep him nil-per-mouth in case immediate endoscopic removal is required. In a randomized trial that enrolled asymptomatic children who had a coin in the esophagus and no esophageal or tracheal pathology, 25% to 30% of the children spontaneously passed the coin beyond the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) with no complications during 8 to 16 hours of observation.

Key learning point: Children with an esophageal foreign body require urgent endoscopic removal only if they have swallowed a button battery, have a history of tracheal or esophageal surgery, or have symptoms of respiratory distress, emesis, or pain.

B) INCORRECT:

Urgent endoscopy is not necessary, given the absence of symptoms or a history of esophageal pathology. Because the coin may pass spontaneously, observation may spare the child the risks of endoscopy and general anesthesia.

C) INCORRECT:

No further diagnostic imaging, such as a barium esophagram, is required given the clear history of ingestion, radiographic evidence, and absence of symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Discharging this patient would be inappropriate because if the coin does not pass the LES spontaneously, it would require endoscopic removal.

E) INCORRECT:

Syrup of ipecac would confer a risk for aspiration and is not indicated for foreign-body removal.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents after she admitted to swallowing toy magnets at a friend’s house earlier that day. She had no symptoms at home.
Examination reveals a nondistended, nontender abdomen with active bowel sounds. A two-view radiograph of the abdomen shows two spherical foreign bodies in the umbilical region of the abdomen with no signs of obstruction. The patient is given polyethylene glycol without electrolytes.
Serial radiographs taken 6 and 12 hours later reveal no interval progression of the magnets. The patient remains asymptomatic with normal vital signs and a normal physical examination.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this case?

choices.text: Discharge to home with a follow-up radiograph in 3 days to see if the magnets have passed
Perform a CT scan using oral contrast to better evaluate the positions of the magnets
Continue serial abdominal radiographs until the magnets are expelled or signs of obstruction develop
Arrange for surgical or endoscopic removal of the magnets

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Conservative management could be considered for ingestion of a single magnet, but not multiple magnets. In the case of a single magnet, the patient can often be sent home and managed with serial radiographs until the foreign body is expelled completely. The exception is if the single magnet is in the esophagus or stomach and the patient is at high risk for additional ingestion; then, removal would be considered.

B) INCORRECT:

CT with enteral contrast is not indicated and is potentially dangerous, as nonprogression of multiple magnets may suggest bowel-wall injury and place the patient at high risk for bowel perforation.

C) INCORRECT:

If the magnets have moved beyond the stomach and are traveling together, and the patient is asymptomatic, the magnets may be followed with serial radiographs. Administration of an osmotic laxative, such as polyethylene glycol, may be tried to enhance passage. If serial radiographs show no evidence that the magnets are progressing (as in this case), the magnets should be removed.

D) INCORRECT:

Initiation of a stimulant laxative would not be safe because multiple magnets may entrap loops of bowel and place the patient at risk for further complications.

E) CORRECT:

Multiple magnets pose a unique risk when ingested together, as they may attract one another through different loops of bowel and can cause mural pressure necrosis. This type of injury may result in bowel perforation, fistula formation, volvulus, obstruction, and intra-abdominal sepsis. The increased risk for complications necessitates inpatient management until the magnets are expelled or removed.

If multiple magnets are in the stomach or esophagus, prompt removal by endoscopy is indicated.

Key learning point: For a child who has swallowed multiple magnets traveling together past the stomach, with no evidence of further progression on serial radiographs, the most appropriate next step is surgical or endoscopic removal.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy is brought in for evaluation after having diminished appetite for the past 12 hours. His mother reports that he was in his usual state of health until earlier in the day when he had a bout of emesis. Since then, he has had four additional episodes of emesis, will not tolerate any solid foods, and has only taken sips of liquids.
On physical examination, he is afebrile and has an oxygen saturation of 99% while breathing ambient air. His lung fields are clear on auscultation. He has no erythema in the oral cavity or oropharynx and no tenderness in the neck. His abdomen is soft. A two-view chest radiograph is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate?

choices.text: Use of cathartics to induce vomiting
CT of the neck and chest with contrast
Trial of oral feeding to allow the foreign body to pass to the stomach

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Induction of vomiting is not recommended in this case. Button batteries can result in esophageal mucosa necrosis within 60 minutes of ingestion, placing the patient at risk for esophageal perforation. Vomiting may expand the perforation and risk mediastinitis.

B) INCORRECT:

CT of the neck and chest is not necessary in this case. The radiograph provides adequate information for diagnosis, and additional imaging will only delay battery removal.

C) INCORRECT:

Rigid bronchoscopy would be appropriate for a foreign body in the airway but not the esophagus. Given the structural composition of the trachea and the lack of cartilage posteriorly, a round foreign body lodged in the trachea will typically rest in the anteroposterior direction, rather than horizontally, and will therefore appear as a vertical line in the anteroposterior view. This is the reverse of how an esophageal foreign body appears on two-view radiograph, as demonstrated in this case.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has a button battery lodged in his esophagus, as indicated by his radiographs. Recognizing the shape of the battery compared to any other foreign body is critical because it affects management. On the anteroposterior radiographic view, a button battery will appear circular with a rim or halo effect near the lateral edge. On the lateral view, the battery will appear as a smaller and larger coin stuck together, creating a rim or step-off. Obtaining a two-view radiograph is critical because the step-off can be missed if only an anteroposterior view is obtained.

When a battery ingestion is identified, esophagoscopy with removal should ideally be completed within 2 hours of the ingestion time to reduce morbidity and mortality. The longer the battery remains in the esophagus, the greater the degree of mucosal breakdown. Unrecognized battery ingestions lead to large perforations of the esophagus and can even result in tracheal perforations.

Key learning point: A double rim on a radiopaque esophageal foreign body is consistent with a button battery.

E) INCORRECT:

A trial of oral intake can be attempted when a coin or magnet ingestion is suspected but should never be considered with button battery ingestion. It will delay definitive treatment and increase the risk of esophageal damage.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy has drooling and chest discomfort after swallowing a coin-shaped battery. X-ray shows the battery in the esophagus. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Button battery ingestion in the esophagus poses a significant risk due to rapid tissue injury. The battery can generate an electrical current, leading to hydroxide ion production and liquefaction necrosis. This can cause severe complications such as perforation and fistula formation. The esophagus is particularly vulnerable due to its thin wall and proximity to vital structures. Endoscopy allows for both diagnosis and prompt retrieval of the battery, minimizing tissue damage. Immediate intervention is crucial to prevent morbidity associated with battery ingestion in children.

Key learning point: Ingestion of a battery lodged in the esophagus is a medical emergency requiring immediate endoscopic removal to prevent serious complications.

B) INCORRECT:

Observation is appropriate for inert foreign bodies like coins in the stomach, but not for batteries in the esophagus. Batteries can cause rapid tissue injury through electrical discharge and caustic burns. Symptoms like drooling and chest discomfort indicate local injury. Observation does not address the risk of severe esophageal injury from battery ingestion.

C) INCORRECT:

Repeating radiography may confirm the battery's location, but the risk of rapid mucosal injury from electrical discharge and caustic leakage is high. Symptoms such as drooling and chest discomfort suggest ongoing esophageal irritation. Delaying intervention for imaging can lead to irreversible injury. Immediate endoscopic retrieval is necessary to prevent complications.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous proton pump inhibitors reduce gastric acid secretion but do not address the mechanism of injury from a battery lodged in the esophagus. The injury is due to electrical current and caustic leakage, causing rapid tissue necrosis. PPIs do not mitigate the risk of complications like perforation and fistula formation.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with a 6-hour history of irritability and food refusal after playing with household items. The child is unable to swallow liquids and has intermittent drooling. Vital signs are normal with mild tachypnea. Physical examination shows pooling of saliva and occasional coughing. Chest x-ray shows a radiopaque circular object at the level of the clavicle. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Observation with repeat imaging in 1 week

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Prolonged observation is contraindicated for esophageal foreign bodies because delaying removal increases the risk for complications such as mucosal ulceration, perforation, and aspiration pneumonia.

B) INCORRECT:

Emergency endoscopy within 2 hours is reserved for complete esophageal obstruction, respiratory distress, button batteries in the esophagus, or sharp objects in the esophagus. This patient has an incomplete obstruction, indicated by intermittent drooling, and requires an alternative management approach.

C) INCORRECT:

Elective endoscopy is inappropriate for esophageal foreign bodies because they do not pass spontaneously. Delaying removal for 48–72 hours increases the risk for complications such as perforation and aspiration.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Esophageal foreign bodies other than batteries or sharp objects require urgent endoscopy within 24 hours. The radiopaque object at the clavicle level indicates impaction at the cricopharyngeal muscle. The patient's drooling and inability to swallow liquids confirms an esophageal obstruction, warranting urgent but not emergency intervention.

E) INCORRECT:

Conservative management is not appropriate for any type of esophageal foreign body. Foreign bodies in the esophagus require active removal because they will not pass spontaneously into the stomach.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the ED by her parents 12 hours after they witnessed her ingest a small metallic object. The child has been eating and drinking normally without vomiting or abdominal pain. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination shows no distress and a soft nontender abdomen. Abdominal x-ray shows a radiopaque object 2.6 cm in diameter in the antrum of the stomach. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Conservative management with serial imaging is appropriate for blunt objects < 2.5 cm in diameter and < 6 cm in length. This object is 2.6 cm in diameter, requiring an alternative approach.

B) INCORRECT:

Urgent endoscopic removal within 24 hours is indicated for symptomatic patients and/or those with sharp objects or multiple magnets in the stomach. This patient is asymptomatic and has ingested a blunt object; therefore, urgent intervention is not indicated.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- Elective endoscopic removal is the most appropriate management for objects > 2.5 cm in diameter in the stomach. At 2.6 cm, this object is too large to pass through the pylorus, making elective removal the most appropriate management.

D) INCORRECT:

Emergency endoscopic removal within 2 hours is reserved for button batteries in the esophagus, esophageal obstruction, or respiratory distress. This asymptomatic patient with a gastric foreign body does not meet the criteria for an emergency procedure.

E) INCORRECT:

Surgical consult is indicated for unsuccessful endoscopic removal, signs of perforation or obstruction, or inability of the foreign object to pass through the GI tract after an appropriate observation period. This patient is stable and has no immediate surgical indications.
